question:
Select the option that can substitute/replace the bracketed word correctly and complete the sentence.
He (seek) for the wallet in his pocket.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 18-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer: Sought

Explanation:
The verb "sought" is the correct past tense of "seek", which means to look for something. The sentence is in the past tense, so "sought" correctly replaces "(seek)" to form:
"He sought for the wallet in his pocket."

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
If I w̲a̲s̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲q̲u̲e̲e̲n̲, I would give a handsome sum towards education.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 12-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: were the queen

Explanation:

The sentence is a hypothetical or unreal condition (contrary-to-fact condition), and in such cases, the correct form is "were" instead of "was" for all subjects, especially with the verb "to be" in the subjunctive mood.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Transnational linkages, for example, sever the nation-state’s i̲n̲t̲e̲g̲r̲i̲t̲y̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲c̲o̲r̲r̲u̲p̲t̲ state-society relations.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 19-Sep Shift 1.)
solution:
The correct answer is: a

The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is:

"cohesion and erode"

So, the revised sentence would be: "Transnational linkages, for example, sever the nation-state’s cohesion and erode state-society relations."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
She was foolish enough to think that she b̲e̲ ̲c̲o̲m̲p̲l̲e̲t̲e̲l̲y̲ ̲s̲a̲f̲e̲ now.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 19-Sep Shift 2.)
solution:
The correct answer is: d

The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment is "were completely safe."

So, the corrected sentence is: "She was foolish enough to think that she were completely safe now."

This option correctly matches the past tense and subjunctive mood of the original sentence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Beyond skills, experience, and training, companies search for applicants who display excitement — those they believe s̲h̲a̲l̲l̲ ̲c̲a̲r̲r̲y̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲a̲l̲l̲o̲c̲a̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲r̲e̲s̲p̲o̲n̲s̲i̲b̲i̲l̲i̲t̲i̲e̲s̲ cheerfully and cooperatively.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 12-Sep Shift 3)
option_2: shall take up any designated obligations
option_4: should pick up all skills and works
solution:
Correct Answer: - will execute assigned duties

Explanation:
The sentence focuses on applicants who display excitement and are believed to perform responsibilities cheerfully and cooperatively. The phrase "will execute assigned duties" best conveys this idea clearly and concisely.

question:
Select the option that correctly describes the use of the word ‘walking’ in the following sentence.
Walking is good for health.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 GL : 21 June Shift-3 GL)
option_1: Walking is the present participle form of the verb functioning as a gerund.
option_2: Walking is the past participle form of the verb.
option_3: Walking is the present tense form of the verb.
option_4: Walking is the base form of the verb.
solution:
The correct answer is: Walking is the present participle form of the verb functioning as a gerund.

In the sentence "Walking is good for health," the word "walking" is a present participle (the "-ing" form of the verb), and it functions as a gerund, which is a verb form used as a noun. Here, "walking" is the subject of the sentence, acting as a noun.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
I h̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲b̲e̲e̲n̲ ̲y̲e̲t̲ to go to the flower exhibition at Delhi University.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 GL : 20 June Shift-3 GL)
solution:
The correct answer is: have yet.

Explanation:

The phrase "have been yet" is incorrect in this context. The correct structure is "have yet to [do something]", which means that the action has not been done but is expected to happen in the future.

Corrected sentence: I have yet to go to the flower exhibition at Delhi University.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The plot of the story e̲f̲f̲e̲c̲t̲s̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲c̲h̲a̲r̲a̲c̲t̲e̲r̲ and their growth.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 GL : 25 June Shift-3 GL)
solution:
The correct answer is:

affects the character

Explanation:

  • "Affect" is a verb meaning to influence or have an impact on something. In this context, the plot of the story impacts the character, so "affects" is appropriate.

  • "Effect" is a noun meaning the result or outcome, which doesn't fit here.

  • The correct verb form, "affects," aligns with the singular subject "The plot of the story."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
Not a word d̲i̲d̲n̲’̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲y̲ ̲s̲p̲e̲a̲k̲ to the others about the sad turn of events.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-2)
solution:
The most appropriate substitution for the underlined segment is "did they speak".

Explanation:

The sentence uses an inverted structure for emphasis, and the correct auxiliary verb for the past tense is "did."

  • No substitution: Incorrect because "didn't they speak" contradicts the intended meaning. The sentence is meant to emphasize that they did not speak a single word, not to form a question.

  • Did they speak: Correct because it maintains the proper grammatical structure for an inverted, emphatic sentence in the past tense.

  • Do they speak: Incorrect because "do" is used for the present tense, not the past.

  • Had they speak: Incorrect because "had" requires the past participle "spoken," not "speak."

Thus, the correct substitution is "did they speak."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Before she began, she asked the teacher whether s̲h̲e̲ ̲w̲r̲i̲t̲e̲ with a pen or a pencil.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-2)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is:

"she should write"

Explanation:

  • The sentence involves reported speech, and the context suggests the speaker is asking for guidance or permission about what to use (pen or pencil). In this case, "she should write" correctly conveys the sense of asking what is appropriate or required.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • "she can write" – This suggests asking about ability, not suitability or preference.

  • "she did write" – This changes the tense and meaning entirely, implying past action rather than seeking permission or advice.

  • "she wrote" – This changes the meaning and does not fit the context of a question being asked before beginning.

Corrected Sentence:

"Before she began, she asked the teacher whether she should write with a pen or a pencil."

Thus, the correct answer is "she should write."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He w̲a̲n̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲v̲i̲s̲i̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-1)
solution:
The most appropriate substitution for the underlined segment is "wanted to visit."

The sentence should read: "He wanted to visit the Golden Temple in Amritsar."

The structure "wanted to + base form of the verb" is grammatically correct. The other options contain errors:

  • "wanted to visited": The verb "visit" should be in its base form, not in the past tense.

  • "wanted to be visit": The phrase is incorrect, as the verb should be in the base form.

  • "wanted to visitor": "Visitor" is a noun, not a verb, so it's incorrect in this context.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
I̲f̲ ̲I̲ ̲w̲a̲s̲ ̲v̲e̲r̲y̲ ̲r̲i̲c̲h̲, I would spend all my time and money for the poor.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-3)
option_1: If I have much riches
option_2: If I were very rich
option_3: If I am very rich
solution:
The correct option is: If I were very rich

Explanation:

In conditional sentences that express hypothetical or unreal situations in the present, the verb 'were' is used with the subject 'I', regardless of whether it is singular or plural. Hence, 'If I were very rich' is the grammatically correct choice.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Shakespeare i̲s̲ ̲g̲r̲e̲a̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ any other English poet.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-1)
solution:
Sentence is referring to Shakespeare's historical context and comparing him to other poets in the past, "was greater than" would be the correct choice.

For example:
"Shakespeare was greater than any other English poet."
This implies a comparison in the past, where Shakespeare is being evaluated against other poets from his time.

So, if the sentence is intended to reflect Shakespeare's historical greatness, "was greater than" would be correct.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Anya w̲a̲s̲ ̲a̲ ̲e̲m̲p̲a̲t̲h̲ and had accurate intuitions regarding other people’s feelings.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 11 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer: - was an empath

Explanation:

  • The sentence describes Anya as someone who is empathetic, and the correct structure for the past tense of the verb "to be" is "was an empath".

  • "Empath" is a noun, and "was" is the past tense of "is," which fits the subject and tense of the sentence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute (replace) the bracketed segment in the following sentence.
I look forward (see) you soon.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 11 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer: - to seeing

Explanation:

The correct phrase is "look forward to", which is always followed by a gerund (verb + "ing" form). Therefore, the correct phrase is "look forward to seeing you soon".

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
My mom made her muffins, but s̲h̲e̲ ̲d̲i̲d̲n̲’̲t̲ ̲e̲a̲t̲ ̲n̲o̲n̲e̲.̲

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer:
she didn’t eat any

Explanation:
The sentence uses a negative construction "didn't," which should be followed by the base form of the verb ("eat"). "Any" is the correct word to use in negative statements to indicate an absence of something.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
While I was waiting for Asha f̲o̲r̲ ̲s̲h̲o̲p̲p̲i̲n̲g̲, I spilled lemonade on my new trousers

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 11 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
The correct answer is: "to shop"

Explanation:

The phrase "waiting for Asha to shop" is the most appropriate option. The expression "waiting for someone to do something" is a common construction in English, indicating that you were waiting for Asha to engage in the activity of shopping.

So, the sentence should read: "While I was waiting for Asha to shop, I spilled lemonade on my new trousers."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The patient couldn’t survive the injuries and s̲u̲c̲c̲u̲m̲b̲e̲d̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ ̲d̲e̲a̲t̲h̲.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: succumbed to death

Explanation:

The correct phrase is "succumbed to" when referring to someone yielding or giving way to death or illness.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
What do you like to do on your free days other than t̲o̲ ̲w̲a̲t̲c̲h̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲m̲o̲v̲i̲e̲s̲?

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 11 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer:watching movies

Explanation:

The phrase “other than” requires a gerund (the -ing form of the verb) to maintain grammatical consistency. “Watching movies” is the correct choice as it follows the same grammatical pattern.

question:
Select the option that can replace the underlined phrase and make the sentence grammatically correct.
I don’t trust my friend because he h̲a̲s̲ ̲n̲o̲t̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲c̲a̲n̲ ̲n̲e̲v̲e̲r̲ ̲b̲e̲ trusted because of his deeds.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 11 Dec Shift-1)
option_1: has not and can’t be
option_2: has not be and can never be
option_3: has not been and can never be
option_4: has been not and can never be
solution:
Correct Answer:has not been and can never be

Explanation:
The correct phrase here is "has not been" because the sentence refers to something that has not happened in the past and is unlikely to happen in the future. "Can never be" is used correctly to show the impossibility in the future.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
A questionnaire w̲i̲l̲l̲ ̲d̲i̲s̲t̲r̲i̲b̲u̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ to all the participants at the end of the session.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
Explanation:

  • The original sentence: “A questionnaire will distributing to all the participants…” is grammatically incorrect.

  • After “will”, we need either:

  • base form of the verb: will distribute (for active voice), or

  • “be” + past participle: will be distributed (for passive voice)

  • Since "a questionnaire" is the receiver of the action, the passive voice is appropriate.

✅ Correct sentence:
A questionnaire will be distributed to all the participants at the end of the session.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence to improve it. If no improvement is required, select ‘No improvement required’.
She h̲a̲s̲ ̲g̲i̲v̲e̲n̲ a brilliant dance performance last week.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The sentence is in the past time frame ("last week"), so the verb should be in simple past tense. The underlined part "has given" is in present perfect tense, which is incorrect because present perfect is not used with specific past time expressions like "last week".
Option B: "gave" is correct as it uses simple past tense, matching the time expression.
Option A: "was giving" is incorrect as it implies an action in progress, which doesn’t fit here.
Option C: "had been given" is incorrect because it is in passive past perfect continuous, and does not fit the active subject and structure.
Option D: "No improvement required" is incorrect because tense mismatch exists.
Answer: Option B (gave).

question:
Select the most appropriate option to improve the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘No improvement’.
My sister r̲e̲s̲e̲m̲b̲l̲e̲s̲ ̲t̲o̲ my mother a lot in looks and in temperament.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The verb "resemble" means "to look like or be similar to" and it is a transitive verb, so it does not take a preposition like "to".
The correct usage is: "My sister resembles my mother..."

Option A: "has resemblance to" is grammatically correct but awkward and unnecessarily wordy.
Option B: "is resembling to" is incorrect because "resemble" is not used in continuous tense and still wrongly includes "to".
Option C: "No improvement" is incorrect because the original sentence uses "resembles to", which is wrong.
Option D: "resembles" is the correct and concise choice.

Answer: Option D (resembles).

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence to improve it. If no improvement is required, select ‘No improvement required’.
By next summer, I will have completed my internship and w̲i̲l̲l̲ ̲h̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲r̲e̲t̲u̲r̲n̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲s̲c̲h̲o̲o̲l̲.̲ ̲

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The sentence begins with "By next summer, I will have completed...", which is in future perfect tense.
The second part "will have returned to school" correctly continues the future perfect structure.

This tense is used to describe an action that will be completed before a specific time in the future.

All verb forms and the sentence structure are grammatically correct.

Option A: No improvement required – ✔ Correct
Option B: will return to school – ❌ future simple, doesn't match the tense
Option C: have returned to school – ❌ present perfect, incorrect
Option D: returned to school – ❌ past tense, doesn't fit future context

Answer: Option A (No improvement required).

question:
Select the most appropriate option to improve the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘No improvement’.
Some students think that if they cram a few chapters, they can p̲a̲s̲s̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲e̲x̲a̲m̲.̲

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
option_2: be passed in the exam
solution:
Solution:
The phrase "pass in the exam" is incorrect in standard English usage. The correct expression is simply "pass the exam" – we don’t use "in" after "pass" when referring to exams.

Correct sentence:
"Some students think that if they cram a few chapters, they can pass the exam."

Option A: No improvement – ❌ incorrect due to wrong preposition
Option B: be passed in the exam – ❌ incorrect passive construction
Option C: pass in an exam – ❌ still incorrect usage of "in"
Option D: pass the exam – ✔ correct and idiomatic usage

Answer: Option D (pass the exam).

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence to improve it. If no improvement is required, select ‘No improvement required’.
As bombs keep falling on Gaza, hundreds of thousands of children h̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲b̲e̲e̲n̲ ̲o̲r̲d̲e̲r̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲f̲l̲e̲e̲ their homes.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
option_1: have been ordered to flee
option_2: has been ordered to flee
solution:
Solution:
The correct phrase should be "have been ordered to flee" – this uses the proper passive voice construction with "ordered" (past participle) and "to flee" (infinitive verb).

Let’s review the options:

  • have been ordered to flee – ✔ grammatically correct and contextually appropriate

  • has been ordered to flee – ❌ subject is "hundreds of thousands of children" (plural), so "have" is required, not "has"

  • have been ordered fleeing – ❌ incorrect verb form; "to flee" is the correct usage

  • No improvement required – ❌ the original "have been order to flee" is grammatically incorrect ("order" should be "ordered")

Answer: Option A (have been ordered to flee)

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
We can go on a vacation if e̲v̲e̲r̲y̲o̲n̲e̲ ̲i̲s̲ ̲a̲g̲r̲e̲e̲i̲n̲g̲.̲

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:
The correct improvement is "everyone agrees" because the verb should match the present simple tense required by the conditional structure “if + present simple.”

  • “is agreeing” is incorrect as “agree” is a stative verb and not normally used in continuous form.

  • “everyone will agreeing” is grammatically wrong; “will” should be followed by base verb, not present participle.

  • “is agree” is also incorrect as it combines an auxiliary verb with a base verb improperly.

So, the correct sentence is:
We can go on a vacation if everyone agrees.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
As I have no time to discuss the points, s̲o̲ ̲I̲ ̲w̲r̲o̲t̲e̲ ̲a̲ ̲e̲m̲a̲i̲l̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲h̲e̲r̲.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 2))
option_1: so I wrote a e-mail to her
option_2: I wrote an email to her
option_3: so I wrote an e-mail for her
option_4: I write an email to her
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is:

I wrote an email to her.

So, the sentence would read:
"As I have no time to discuss the points, I wrote an email to her."

Explanation:

  • I wrote an email to her is the grammatically correct option, as it correctly uses the past tense ("wrote") and proper article usage ("an" before email).

  • so I wrote a e-mail to her is incorrect because "a" should be replaced with "an" before "email."

  • so I wrote an e-mail for her is incorrect because the phrase "for her" changes the meaning — it suggests the email was written on her behalf, which is not the intended meaning.

  • I write an email to her is incorrect because it uses the present tense ("write") instead of the past tense ("wrote") needed for this context.

Thus, "I wrote an email to her" is the correct substitution.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
This win could e̲n̲h̲a̲n̲c̲e̲ to be a historic turning point in the fortunes of the team.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 4))
solution:
The most appropriate option to improve the underlined part of the sentence is "prove."

Explanation:

  • "Prove" fits well in this context, as it suggests that the win can serve as evidence or a way to establish the historic turning point in the team's fortunes.

Let’s look at the other options:

  • "Confirm" means to make something certain, but it doesn’t convey the same meaning of showing or establishing something as "prove" does.

  • "Accomplish" means to achieve something, which doesn’t fit the context of suggesting that the win demonstrates a turning point.

  • "Demonstrate" also means to show or reveal something, but "prove" is more specific in this context because it implies the win will establish that it is indeed a historic turning point.

Thus, the correct answer is "prove."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
The plum tree in our garden ̲i̲s̲ ̲c̲o̲v̲e̲r̲ ̲i̲n̲ blossoms, as are the trees outside my office window.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 1))
solution:
The correct answer is "is covered in".

Explanation:

  • The original sentence has "is cover in", which is grammatically incorrect. The verb "cover" should be in the past participle form ("covered") because it is used in the passive voice ("is covered in").

  • The passive construction is necessary here because the tree is being covered by the blossoms; the blossoms are doing the action of covering.

Options Analysis:

  • are cover at: Incorrect, because "are" does not agree with the singular subject "The plum tree," and "cover at" is not idiomatic.

  • is covered in: Correct, as it uses the correct passive form and matches the singular subject.

  • No substitution required: Incorrect, because the original phrase "is cover in" is grammatically incorrect.

  • is covering at: Incorrect, because "covering" suggests a continuous action, which does not fit the context, and "at" is not the correct preposition.

Correct Sentence:

"The plum tree in our garden is covered in blossoms, as are the trees outside my office window."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The dictator ordered the traitor w̲e̲r̲e̲ jailed.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 1))
solution:
The correct substitution for the underlined phrase is "to be", which forms part of the structure used in indirect speech or passive voice constructions after verbs like "ordered." Here's the corrected sentence:

"The dictator ordered the traitor to be jailed."

Explanation:

  • "To be" is used because it's part of the infinitive form that follows the verb "ordered," indicating the action the dictator wanted to happen.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
Then I unfurled the Indian tri-colour and k̲e̲e̲p̲ it aloft at the roof of the world.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 3))
solution:
The most appropriate substitution for the underlined segment is:

"held"

Here’s why:

  • "Held" is the correct past tense form of "hold," and it fits the context of the sentence, where the speaker is describing an action they performed in the past.

Let’s analyze the other options:

  • "Keeping": This is the present participle form and doesn’t fit in the context where a past action is being described.

  • "Hold": This is the base form of the verb and is not suitable for the past tense.

  • "No substitution required": The word "keep" should be changed to "held" to maintain proper grammatical consistency.

Thus, the correct choice is "held", as it appropriately aligns with the past tense of the action.

question:
Select the option that will improve the given sentence by using the most appropriate verb.
That Macbook belong to Xavier.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 4))
option_1: That Macbook is belonged to Xavier.
option_2: That Macbook belonging to Xavier.
option_3: That Macbook belongs to Xavier.
option_4: That Macbook is belong to Xavier.
solution:
The most appropriate option to improve the sentence is:

"That Macbook belongs to Xavier."

Here’s why:

  • "Belongs" is the correct verb form in the present tense, third-person singular. The sentence is talking about something that currently belongs to Xavier, so this is the proper form.

Let’s analyze the other options:

  • "That Macbook is belonged to Xavier.": "Belonged" is the past tense, and "is belonged" is not grammatically correct.

  • "That Macbook belonging to Xavier.": This is an incomplete sentence and doesn’t have a proper verb.

  • "That Macbook is belong to Xavier.": The phrase "is belong" is grammatically incorrect; the correct form would be "belongs."

Therefore, the correct choice is "That Macbook belongs to Xavier."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Gulliver h̲e̲a̲r̲ ̲h̲i̲s̲ ̲w̲a̲t̲c̲h̲ ̲t̲i̲c̲k̲i̲n̲g̲ in his pocket.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 1))
option_1: could hear his watch ticked
option_3: could hear his watch ticking
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is "could hear his watch ticking."

Explanation:

  • The correct construction here is "could hear his watch ticking" because it follows the structure of expressing an action that was heard in the past. The use of "could hear" is followed by the continuous action of "ticking."

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • "could hear his watch ticked" – The word "ticked" is in the past tense, which is incorrect in this context. The action of the watch ticking should be in its continuous form.

  • "watch ticking" – This lacks the subject and verb ("could hear") needed to complete the sentence.

  • "heard his watch tickling" – The word "tickling" is incorrect because "tickling" refers to something that causes physical sensation, whereas "ticking" refers to the sound the watch makes.

Final Answer: could hear his watch ticking

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Employers in many developing countries report that a lack of skilled workers is a major and increasing bottleneck for their operations, a̲f̲f̲e̲c̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲i̲r̲ ̲c̲a̲p̲a̲c̲i̲t̲y̲ to innovate.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 2))
solution:
Correct Answer:affecting their capacity

Explanation:

The original sentence is:
“…a lack of skilled workers is a major and increasing bottleneck for their operations, affected their capacity to innovate.”
This is incorrect because the participle "affected" does not logically or grammatically fit after a comma in this structure. We need a present participle to show a continuing impact — that the bottleneck is affecting their capacity.

Let’s look at the options:

  • effect their capacity – ❌ “effect” as a verb means to cause something to happen, not suitable here.

  • affecting their capacity – ✅ present participle; correctly continues the idea of an ongoing consequence.

  • effecting their capacity – ❌ incorrect usage; “effecting” means to bring about, not to influence.

  • affect their capacity – ❌ grammatically needs a subject; doesn’t follow smoothly from the sentence.

✅ Therefore, “affecting their capacity” is the most appropriate substitution.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the following sentence.
There was a noise that w̲a̲s̲ ̲w̲a̲k̲e̲ ̲m̲e̲ ̲u̲p̲.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer:woke me up

Explanation:

The original sentence is:
"There was a noise that was wake me up."
This is grammatically incorrect.

Let’s examine the options:

  • has woke me up – ❌ incorrect tense and form. “Woke” is the past simple, but after “has” we need the past participle “woken.”

  • woke me up – ✅ correct past simple form to match “There was a noise.”

  • wakes me up – ❌ present tense; doesn't match the past “was.”

  • woken me up – ❌ missing auxiliary verb “has” or “had.”

✅ Therefore, the correct and grammatically appropriate substitution is: woke me up.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the following sentence.
P̲l̲a̲y̲ ̲c̲a̲r̲d̲s̲ is not allowed here

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer:Playing cards

Explanation:

The sentence is: "Play cards is not allowed here."

Let’s examine the options:

  • Play card – ❌ Incorrect verb form and singular noun.

  • Playing card – ❌ Refers to one single card, not the activity.

  • Playing cards – ✅ Correct. Refers to the activity of playing with a set of cards.

  • Played cards – ❌ Past tense, not suitable here.

✅ Therefore, the correct substitution is "Playing cards" — “Playing cards is not allowed here.”

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
I like p̲l̲a̲y̲e̲d̲ cricket after school.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:playing

Explanation:

The sentence is: "I like played cricket after school."

This is incorrect because:

  • The verb like is usually followed by a gerund (verb+ing) when referring to general enjoyment of an activity.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • play – ❌ base form; not used directly after “like” in this context.

  • playing – ✅ correct; "I like playing cricket" is the proper structure.

  • having to play – ❌ awkward and changes the meaning.

  • played – ❌ past tense; incorrect after “like.”

✅ Therefore, the correct substitution is "playing".
Correct sentence: I like playing cricket after school.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Yoga may manage pain and h̲e̲l̲p̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲r̲e̲d̲u̲c̲e̲ stress.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:help in reducing

Explanation:

The sentence is: "Yoga may manage pain and helping reduce stress."
This is grammatically incorrect because the verb form after 'may' should be in the base form or follow a parallel gerund structure.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • helped reduce – ❌ past tense; does not match with “may.”

  • help reduction for – ❌ incorrect structure and awkward phrasing.

  • help reduced – ❌ grammatically incorrect; “reduced” is past participle, not suitable here.

  • help in reducing – ✅ correct; this uses “help” followed by a gerund “reducing,” which maintains parallelism with “manage.”

✅ Correct sentence: Yoga may manage pain and help in reducing stress.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can replace the bracketed word segment in the following sentence.
Men (allowed) for Olympic artistic swimming for the first time at the 2024 Paris Games, the IOC confirmed on Thursday.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: are eligible

Explanation:
The sentence talks about a future event (2024 Paris Games) and refers to the official announcement by the IOC that men can now participate in Olympic artistic swimming.

  • Are eligible – ✅ Correct choice. It means that men now have the right or qualification to participate. Matches the official tone and context.

  • Will approve – ❌ Grammatically incorrect and illogical in passive form; also shifts focus to future decision-making rather than a confirmed announcement.

  • Have permitted – ❌ Incorrect subject-verb alignment; also “men have permitted” would mean the men are allowing, which is not the case.

  • Are likely – ❌ Implies uncertainty, whereas the sentence mentions a confirmed development.

Correct sentence:
Men are eligible for Olympic artistic swimming for the first time at the 2024 Paris Games, the IOC confirmed on Thursday.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the following sentence.
I cannot go out tonight because I w̲i̲l̲l̲ ̲p̲r̲e̲p̲a̲r̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲f̲ my interview tomorrow.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 4))
option_1: I had to prepare to
option_2: I have been prepare to
option_3: I have to prepare for
option_4: I will have prepare for
solution:
Correct Answer: I have to prepare for

Explanation:
The sentence should correctly read:
"I cannot go out tonight because I have to prepare for my interview tomorrow."

  • "Have to" expresses a necessity or obligation in the present or near future.

  • "Prepare for" is the correct phrase when getting ready for something (like an interview).

  • Other options are grammatically incorrect:

  • "I had to prepare to" – past tense, doesn't fit with "cannot go out tonight".

  • "I have been prepare to" – incorrect verb form.

  • "I will have prepare for" – grammatically incorrect construction.

Thus, "I have to prepare for" is the correct and grammatically appropriate substitution.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
She ̲f̲i̲n̲i̲s̲h̲e̲d̲ ̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲q̲u̲i̲c̲k̲l̲y̲ ̲b̲r̲e̲a̲k̲f̲a̲s̲t̲ ̲and rushed to school.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 2))
solution:
Correct Answer: (C) finished her breakfast quickly

Explanation:
The sentence structure requires the subject "She" followed by a verb phrase that is grammatically correct and maintains logical order.

Let’s analyze the options:

(A) her breakfast finished quickly – Incorrect; this changes the subject of the action (now the breakfast is doing the action, which is illogical).
(B) quickly her breakfast finished – Incorrect word order; it sounds unnatural and passive.
(C) finished her breakfast quickly – ✅ Correct and natural construction. The verb "finished" is followed by the object "her breakfast", and "quickly" is the adverb describing how the action was done.
(D) finished breakfast hers quickly – Incorrect possessive usage ("breakfast hers" is not standard English).

Therefore, the most appropriate substitution is "finished her breakfast quickly".

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Professor Singh is not in the office today. I a̲s̲k̲ ̲y̲o̲u̲ ̲t̲r̲y̲ ̲c̲a̲l̲l̲ him tomorrow.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 3))
option_3: ask you to try called
solution:
Correct Answer: suggest you try calling

Explanation:
The correct and natural way to advise someone is to say "I suggest you try calling".

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • asked you to call – Incorrect; changes the meaning to past tense and a direct command.

  • am suggesting you calling – Incorrect; incorrect verb form.

  • ask you to try called – Incorrect; incorrect verb forms and structure.

  • suggest you try calling – ✅ Correct; proper structure and polite suggestion.

So, the correct sentence is:
"Professor Singh is not in the office today. I suggest you try calling him tomorrow."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select 'No substitution required'.
The keys were l̲i̲e̲s̲ ̲o̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲t̲a̲b̲l̲e̲.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.14_09-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct sentence:
The keys were lying on the table.

Explanation:

  • The original sentence says: "The keys were lies on the table." which is grammatically incorrect because "lies" is the present tense form of the verb "to lie" (meaning to rest or be situated), but it does not fit with the past auxiliary verb "were".

  • When using the past continuous tense, the correct verb form after "were" should be the -ing form of the verb. So, "lying" is the correct form.

  • The phrase "were lying" indicates an action that was ongoing in the past (the keys were resting on the table at that time).

question:
Recognise the sentence with the correct transitive verb form of break.
A. The cyclone broke the window.
B.The window broke.
C. The cyclone caused the breaking of window.
D.The cyclone caused the broken window.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.15_14-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

  • A transitive verb is a verb that requires a direct object to complete its meaning.

  • In the sentence “The cyclone broke the window”, the verb "broke" is transitive because it acts upon the object "the window".

  • Let's analyse other options:

  • B. The window broke. → "broke" is intransitive here; no object.

  • C. The cyclone caused the breaking of window. → Grammatically awkward; not using the simple transitive verb form.

  • D. The cyclone caused the broken window. → Passive construction; not using the transitive verb "broke" directly.

Hence, Option A is correct as it uses "broke" as a transitive verb properly.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
I long from travel outside the country, dreaming of adventures among the towering Alps and basking in the turquoise waters of the Caribbean.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.2_30-Sep_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: long to travel

Explanation:

  • The correct expression is "long to travel" which means having a strong desire to travel.

  • "Long for travelling" is grammatically incorrect here because after "long," the infinitive form ("to travel") is used, not the gerund ("travelling").

  • "Long for travelled" and "long at travel" are incorrect phrases.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
We can observed from the poll that the award is likely to go to the horror movie director this year.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.21_16-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: can observe from

Explanation:

  • The original sentence uses "can observed", which is grammatically incorrect. The correct modal + verb structure is "can observe" (modal "can" + base verb "observe").

  • So, the corrected sentence should be:
    "We can observe from the poll that the award is likely to go to the horror movie director this year."

This version is grammatically correct and conveys the intended meaning clearly.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.

Siliguri h̲a̲s̲ ̲j̲o̲i̲n̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲n̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲c̲e̲l̲e̲b̲r̲a̲t̲e̲ the golden jubilee of the first conquest of Mount Everest by an Indian.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.30_21-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: joined the national celebration

Explanation:

  • The phrase "joined the nation to celebrate" is awkward and incorrect here.

  • The correct and natural phrase is "joined the national celebration," which means Siliguri participated in the country's celebration.

Other options:

  • "joins the celebratory nation" – incorrect grammar and awkward phrasing

  • "joining the nation celebrate" – incorrect form

  • "No improvement required" – not correct as the original phrase is awkward

Correct sentence:
"Siliguri joined the national celebration of the golden jubilee of the first conquest of Mount Everest by an Indian."

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
Mukta r̲e̲q̲u̲e̲s̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲N̲i̲k̲i̲t̲a̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲s̲h̲a̲r̲e̲ the picture taken during the wedding.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.40_28-Oct_Shift-2)
option_3: will requests Nikita to share
solution:
Answer:No improvement required

Explanation:
The sentence:
Mukta requested Nikita to share the picture taken during the wedding.

This is grammatically correct.

  • The verb "requested" is in the past tense and correctly followed by the structure "to + base verb" (to share).

  • The object "Nikita" correctly comes after the verb, indicating who is being requested.

Let’s review the options:

  • requesting Nikita to share – ❌ changes the tense unnecessarily

  • will requests Nikita to share – ❌ incorrect tense and verb form

  • requested Nikita for share – ❌ ungrammatical; "for share" is incorrect

  • No improvement required – ✅ the sentence is already correct

So, the correct answer is No improvement required.

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence from the given options.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.45_30-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: The responsibility was given to each student to keep quieter during the seminar.
option_2: The responsibility is given to each student to keep quieter during the seminar.
option_3: The responsibility was give to each student to keep quieter during the seminar.
option_4: The responsibility was given to each student to keep quiet during the seminar.
solution:
Answer:The responsibility was given to each student to keep quiet during the seminar.

Explanation:
Let’s analyse the options one by one:

  • "The responsibility was given to each student to keep quieter during the seminar."
    ❌ Incorrect – "quieter" is a comparative form used when comparing two things. Here, we simply need "quiet."

  • "The responsibility is given to each student to keep quieter during the seminar."
    ❌ Incorrect – same issue with "quieter" and also the tense "is given" is present, while the context suggests past tense.

  • "The responsibility was give to each student..."
    ❌ Incorrect – "give" should be "given" (past participle form).

  • "The responsibility was given to each student to keep quiet during the seminar."
    ✅ Correct – proper tense, correct verb form, and correct use of "quiet" (शांत).

So, the grammatically correct sentence is:
The responsibility was given to each student to keep quiet during the seminar.
